question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
Suppose you are given a set of \emph{N} data points
\emph{(x\textsubscript{n}, y\textsubscript{n})}, with
\emph{x\textsubscript{n}} increasing, and you wish to interpolate these
points with a spline function \emph{$f$}, where \emph{$f$(x)} is given by
the cubic polynomial \emph{p\textsubscript{n}(x)} on each interval
\emph{(x\textsubscript{n}, x\textsubscript{n+1})} for \emph{n = 1, ...,
N-1}:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p_n(x) = a_n(x-x_n)^3 + b_n(x-x_n)^2 + c_n(x-x_n) + d_n\end{align*}

\textbf{(b)} Write down the equations required for \emph{$f$(x)} to have
continuous first and second derivatives. How many equations does this
provide?
sols:
For $\displaystyle f(x)$ to have continuous first derivatives, we must
have $\displaystyle p_i'(x_{i+1}) = p_{i+1}'(x_{i+1})$ . This gives us
N-2 equations because we cannot fit the endpoints to anything.

For $\displaystyle f(x)$ to have continuous second derivatives, we must
have $\displaystyle p_{i}''(x_{i+1}) = p_{i+1}''(x_{i+1})$ . This gives
us N-2 equations because again, we cannot fit the endpoints to anything.

So in total, $\displaystyle (N-2) + (N-2) = 2N - 4$ equations
